name: NPR
text: At least 13 people were killed in a stampede at a nightclub in Peru when they tried to escape police who showed up to enforce COVID-19 restrictions on such gatherings. https://t.co/drpdNt6u50

name: NPR
text: Justin Townes Earle, the award-winning singer-songwriter and son of Steve Earle, has died. He was 38. https://t.co/TAivGGZfPH

name: NPR
text: Since a 2018 investigation by NPR led an overhaul of the troubled TEACH Grant program, the Education Department says more than 6,500 teachers have had nearly $44 million in unfair student debts turned back into grants. https://t.co/vJtWhDqA2n

name: NPR
text:
The House approved a bill to:

• infuse $25 billion into USPS
• block any service or operations changes to USPS until at least January
• require USPS to prioritize delivery of all election-related mail
  
But it's unlikely to advance through the Senate.
https://t.co/d37P39jCh5

name: NPR
text: A Black man was in serious condition after being shot several times by a police officer in Kenosha, Wisc., as authorities responded to a domestic situation, in a scene that was caught on video. https://t.co/4pLPvPYu2a

name: NPR
text:
A federal judge on Thursday dismissed President Trump's latest attempt to block a subpoena for his tax records from Manhattan's district attorney.
https://t.co/jOP7jSSuKq

name: NPR
text:
Nearly 40% of voters in North Carolina are under 40. They make up its most racially diverse voting bloc. Several who spoke to NPR said their desire to defeat Trump outweighs their reservations about Biden.

"Trump got to go, that's all I know," one says.  
https://t.co/xGlE6hzDbm

name: NPR
text:
"Donald Trump not only has a higher percentage of political ambassadors, but has a higher percentage of ambassadors who don't seem to be temperamentally or intellectually suited for the work," says a former U.S. diplomat.
https://t.co/C6DoIHtLkj

name: NPR
text:
A lot of the nuts and bolts of voting in the U.S. can feel like obstacles: registration, showing up at the right polling place, getting time off work to vote. 

@npritsbeenamin Sam Sanders talks with historian Martha S. Jones. https://t.co/rCeS2jMO6L https://t.co/1sNjJM8Qby

name: NPR
text:
An extraordinarily high number of ballots — more than 550,000 — have been rejected in this year's presidential primaries, an NPR analysis finds.

That's far more than the 318,728 ballots rejected in the 2016 general election.
 https://t.co/wFgLE4Vwod

name: NPR
text:
1) Think of a place on earth with a four-word name
2) Take the third word
3) Advance 3 of its letters to the next letter of the alphabet (so A would become B, B would be come C, etc.)
4) You'll get the fourth word in the name. 

What place is this? https://t.co/BuieGwOA6R

name: NPR
text:
In a norm-breaking move criticized by ethics experts, President Trump will deliver his acceptance speech from the White House lawn. 

Ahead of the Republican National Convention, here are 5 questions to note:
https://t.co/vxOcQy2Vu7

name: NPR
text: The redwoods and condors will likely survive the wildfires raging in California, biologists say. The larger question is whether ecosystems can fully bounce back after extreme fires given that the climate change can make recovery difficult. https://t.co/HaHYKgtEjU

name: NPR
text:
Doctors say even when taken off ventilators, some COVID-19 patients remain unconscious for days, weeks or longer. 

They worry medical teams are not waiting long enough for patients to awaken before removing life support.
https://t.co/yAfWzojasQ

name: NPR
text: WATCH LIVE: Postmaster General Louis DeJoy appears before the House Oversight Committee, amid growing concerns that changes made under his leadership could jeopardize the Postal Service’s ability to serve customers. https://t.co/o1Ssf1gYLn
